properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter storm conditions are occuring right now. Total snowfall amounts of close to 15 cm, strong to high westerly winds and blowing snow are expected . Visibilities will be reduced to zero in blowing snow and in heavy snow. The combination of this wet, heavy snow and these strong winds has the potential to cause broken tree limbs. Conditions will improve gradually overnight tonight. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-03T13:59:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-03T03:58:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3424347530.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Great amounts of wet, heavy snow as well as strong winds are expected through Tuesday morning. Total snowfall amounts are expected to approach 5 to 10 centimetres. Quickly accumulating snow and reduced visibilities are expected to create difficult road conditions. The combination of this wet, heavy snow and these strong winds has the potential to cause broken tree limbs. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-03T13:59:38-00:00

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow combined with strong to high northwesterly winds will produce blizzard conditions beginning Tuesday morning. Weather conditions will improve gradually late Tuesday. A blizzard warning is issued when winds are expected to produce blowing snow with widespread visibilities of 400 metres or less for at least 6 hours. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Summary:

Freezing rain will continue this evening and end overnight as the system moves eastward. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A vigorous Pacific frontal system is moving through southern Yukon and northern B.C. today bringing heavy snowfall and local blowing snow. Total snowfall accumulations of 25 to 45 cm are expected. Periods of snow will continue over Cassiar Mountains and Watson Lake this afternoon and early this evening. Heavy snow has ended over Whitehorse, Teslin, and Atlin. Strong northerly winds will also accompany this system producing local blowing snow and poor visibility. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-03T13:37:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-02T21:38:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4110322716.2020
Area: Watson Lake, Cassiar Mountains
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A disturbance tracking across the northern Prairies and its associated warm front will bring mixed precipitation to the Lynn Lake, Leaf Rapids and Pukatawagan areas. The warm front, which straddles the area from northwest to southeast, will be the dividing line between wet snow and rain. Northeast of the front heavy snowfall is expected with snowfall totals of 10 to 15 cm possible by Tuesday morning. Meanwhile, near the front, the precipitation will gradually change over to freezing rain or rain. The main precipitation area is forecast to exit the region by Tuesday morning but some lingering patchy fog, drizzle or freezing drizzle maybe in the area until midday. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-03T13:29:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-02T21:30:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0307069325.2020
Area: Lynn Lake, Leaf Rapids, Pukatawagan
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Ice build-up due to freezing rain is expected or occurring. A nearly stationary band of mixed precipitation will set up and provide a prolonged period of freezing rain and ice pellets to portions of Northern Saskatchewan tonight. Freezing rain amounts will be highly variable, but should generally range from 1-5 mm. The freezing rain and ice pellets are forecast to end west to east beginning overnight. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-03T13:45:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-02T21:46:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1923333545.2020

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. A frontal system carrying sub-tropical moisture is set to arrive on the south coast by early Tuesday. Heavy rain will begin late overnight tonight and persist through early afternoon on Tuesday. Rain will taper off to showers in the afternoon. A second, weaker system will sweep across the region Tuesday night bringing another round of steady rain. Total rainfall amounts of 50 to 80 mm can be expected by Wednesday morning. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-03T15:32:02-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A low pressure system moving across the northern Prairies will bring heavy snowfall to northern Manitoba tonight. Light snow currently in the area will intensify this evening with heavy snow moving through the region overnight but easing off early Tuesday morning. 10 to 15 cm of snow will fall with this system. In addition to the snow, patchy freezing rain is also possible. The most likely area to see the freezing rain will be along a northwest to southeast line south of Thompson and north of Norway House. Any freezing rain which does occur will also also exit the region by Tuesday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
